dataset.title: Accelerated Weathering Effects on Bulk Interfacial Strength of Wood and Thermoplastics

abstract.para: Model composites of birch (B) and rubberwood (R) dowels and 5 types of thermoplastics, namely low-density polyethylene (LDPE), high-density polyethylene (HDPE), polypropylene (PP), polystyrene (PS), and high-impact polystyrene (HIPS), were used to evaluate the effect of weathering conditions on the bulk interfacial shear strength (ISS) of wood-plastic composites using a modified single-fiber pull-out test. Results showed that HDPE, PP, PS, and HIPS were more sensitive to the cyclic humidity tests, while LDPE was less influenced by either the water immersion or cyclic-humidity changes.

section.title: Model composite preparation
section.para: 30g of low-density polyethylene (LDPE), high-density polyethylene (HDPE), polypropylene (PP), polystyrene (PS), and high-impact polystyrene (HIPS) were subjected to ovens of 150, 140, 200, 190, and 190â„ƒ respectively for 2 hours. The pre-prepared 7.0 cm long dowel pins of rubberwood (R) and birch (B) were then embedded in the molten plastic matrices and remained in the ovens for another 30 min. Model composites were made by removing specimens from the ovens and cooled in ambient conditions until room temperature was reached.

section.title: Accelerated weathering
section.para: To assess the effect of accelerated weathering, model composites were subjected to either a water immersion test or a cyclic humidity test. The water immersion test involves immersing model composites in water at room temperatures for 2 hrs (2H) and 24 hrs (24H), and the cyclic humidity test involves exposing model composites in a weather chamber of 25oC and 90% relative humidity for 1week and 25oC and 60% relative humidity for another week. The cyclic humidity test included 1 cycle (2W) and 2 cycles (4W).

section.title: Bulk interfacial shear strength tests
section.para: Bulk interfacial shear strength tests were performed in a Computer-servo Material Testing Machine at a load cell speed of 5 mm min-1, using a tension fixture on the dowel end and an internal bond fixture on the plastic matrix end. The bulk interfacial shear strength (ISS) was determined by dividing the debonding force with the embedded area, which can be calculated by multiplying dowel diameter with the embedded length and the circular constant

dataTable.entityDescription: experiment of accelerated weathering effects on bulk interfacial strength of wood and thermoplstics

attribute.attributeDefinition: B represents species of birch and R is rubber wood for the test

textDomain.definition: with b and r for the code to record

attribute.attributeLabel: plastic type used for the experiment
attribute.attributeDefinition: with codes as follows LDPE for low density polyethylene HDPE for high density polyethyene PP for polyproplene PS for polystyrene and HIPS for high impact polystrne

treatements are wethering conditions mentioned as follows N is no treatment then there are two treatments water immersion in hours 2H for 2 hours 24H for 24 hours Cyclic humidity test in week 2W for 2 weeks 4W for 4 weeks

attribute.attributeLabel: each test sample gave a number
attribute.attributeDefinition: No is the number of test samples from 1
L1 is the length of embeded length measured
L2 is the length of embeded samples measured
